description: Borrowed from Middle French supercherie, itself borrowed from Italian soperchieria.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Foul play; an attack made by deceit. [16th–17th c.]
(now chiefly in French contexts) Deception, deceit; an instance of fraud. [from 17th c.]
examples: We […] should certainly deny to any teacher of morals, in any age, who resorted to such ‘supercherie’ and charlatanism, any very high place among the instructors and benefactors of mankind.
